title: E field - unknown charge for zero field at origin

content.question: Two charged particles are located on the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis of a coordinate system. One particle is at <math alttext="x equals positive d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>d</mi></mpadded></math> and has a charge of <math alttext="negative 4 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math>. The second particle is at <math alttext="x equals positive 4 d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>d</mi></mpadded></math> and has an unknown charge. What charge value on the second particle would result in a net electric field of zero at <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>?

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
